owner: Noatum Logistics UK Cancer Charity Ride
story:
2020 has proved to be a trying time for many of us in light of Covid 19. There is unfortunately another disease that has really been at the forefront of what has already been a tremendously tough year –Cancer.  

Cancer is a disease which many many families are affected by at one time or another and this year it has been a sad personal experience for some of our close colleagues.


We have colleagues currently fighting cancer

We have colleagues that are caring for loved ones who are currently recuperating from cancer treatment  

We have colleagues that have survived cancer but are still left dealing with the long term physical & mental effects of cancer

and we have colleagues who are sadly grieving loved ones lost to cancer this year.  


In light of this, a number of our colleagues will be doing a Charity Ride to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support 

They will set off to complete a 50 Mile Road Bike Ride or a 25 Mile Mountain Bike Ride.

You can support their rides by making a donation to this page. Little or Big, every donation makes a massive impact by supporting cancer research, recovery & care.  

We also encourage as many of you to hop on the bikes too & share your Rides for Cancer on this page!

In Love & Support for our dear colleagues & their loved ones.

And in Loving Memory to those close to us lost to cancer this year.

story:
Citi are aiming to raise 350,000 to enable Guide Dogs to create 178 life-changing partnerships. With our support, Guide Dogs will match people with sight loss on the London waiting list to guide dogs or volunteer sighted guides.

About Our London Charity Partner Guide Dogs

Losing your sight shouldn't also mean losing your independence, confidence and freedom, but unfortunately, our world is a tough place when you cant see. In the UK, there are 360,000 people who are blind or partially sighted and half of them do not leave their homes alone.

Guide Dogs provide life-changing services:
- Guide Dogs
- Volunteer sighted guides (My Guides)
- Support for children and young people
- Orientation and mobility specialists
- Technology
- Support for friends and family

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the JustGiving page in memory of Gerry Crossland.

Gerry sadly passed away on 17th November 2020, peacefully at home aged 82. 

As a child, Gerry spent a lot of time in Great Ormond Street Hospital and it remained a cause close to his heart.

Gerry was a caring and loving husband to Carole, a loving father to Vicky and James as well as a doting grandfather to Elleanor, Jemma, Haydn, Bryce and Ben.

He made many friends over the years from the RAF, Jersey Airport, Santander and UCAS. Besides his professionalism he will be remembered for his wicked and dry sense of humour. He was always the life and soul of the party wherever he was, even to the end. He always had a joke to tell (even if we’d heard it before!)

In view of the current restrictions, we will be having a small ceremony for immediate family on 18th December 2020. Gerry didn’t want any flowers but asked people to kindly make a small donation to his favourite charity - Great Ormond Street Hospital.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We have found a vaccine for COVID in less than a year due to unlimited funds. Imagine if we could do the same for Cancer. Unfortunately, the charity donations in which many are funded have taken a huge drop in revenues this year. So we all need to do what we can to help.

Many of you know that I've aways been fairly strong and chunky but never found it easy to drop weight, especially as I'm getting older. So my challenge isn't going to be an easy one. With gyms closing and opening - then closing again it has been hard to find any rhythm but I need to get on with it.

So how £ 4 lb works is you can donate in two ways. Sponsor a £ for every pound I lose between now December 3 and March 3, or cap the donation to an amount you are comfortable with. I'm grateful for every pound and it's all going a brilliant charity.

So today, December 3, I weigh 16st 5lbs. My goal would be to get close to 14st. A weight I've not been able to achieve in 20 years!

That would be a loss of 32lbs in three months! 

Remember this £ 4 lb format can be copied by anyone for their given charity or fundraiser.

If you have got this far .. thanks again

Alex / Gal

story:
It's with heavy hearts we announce our mother, Dorothy Edith Udall of Nailstone Nuneaton, passed away on Sunday November 29th 2020, from COVID-19 pneumonitis.

Dorothy leaves behind her children Charlotte Rachel and Roger and grandchildren Stephen,Theo, Ethan and Alex.

Our mum devoted her life to her family and friends and will be greatly missed.

Dorothy expressed her wish for a private cremation with no gathering to help the fight against Covid and instead would like all her family and closest friends to attend a small interment service at a later date when it's safe for us to gather and share memories together.

As such her cremation will be private and we invite Family & Friends wishing to honour her memory to make a donation in her name to Cancer Research instead of flowers.

Mum's cremation will be held at 8:20am on Wednesday 9th December and we ask you all join us in minutes of silence and reflection wherever you may be at this time.

The just-giving link below will allow you to donate securely online.

Many thanks

Charlotte Rachel and Roger

story:

Can't make that date? Don't worry, we will be offering the whole show 'on demand' for one week only, so you can watch it again and again at your leisure!

Also, don't forget to gift aid your donation if you're a UK taxpayer - it won't cost you a single penny extra but the charity will receive an extra 50p on top of your £2 ticket donation

story:
We have  done this light display for the last 14 years due to losing my father and many other family members were  received the fantastic support from  the Marie Curie  nurses 

This year, because of the pandemic, we have been sadly unable to hold our ‘big switch on’ fundraising event, however the lights are on & we encourage you to drive by & take a look & give a donation to Marie Curie. This is not as easy as previous years either, so we have moved with the times and set up a Just Giving page to spread the news about our Christmas Light Display and so we can continue to raise vital funds for our local nursing service.

Whatever you can spare to donate when you ‘visit’ the lights will be used to make a difference to someone else at the end of their life.

▪ £20 pays for an hour of expert care and emotional support for someone living with a terminal illness, in the comfort of their own home
▪ £41 kits out a Marie Curie Nurse, so they’re ready to face anything with a smile & the sense of pride that their uniform brings
▪ £1600 sponsors a Registered Nurse for the 12days of Christmas, so they can help the people they care for make the most of what could be their final Christmas with their loved ones

Many thanks 

Tony and Linda

story:
Beth is a Marie Curie nurse, based across South east London, Southwark and Lambeth. She shares her experience of working at Christmas…

‘I’ve worked most Christmases since I’ve been at Marie Curie. Last year I looked after a lady who was very unwell. She was in a lot of pain, so they organised that all the family should come to have Christmas with her. 

It very hard for them, but being there, singing her Christmas songs, helping to unwrap presents, clean up. It was nice. Last Christmas, I also went to a patient who was living alone. Somebody had bought a turkey for him, but he couldn’t cook it himself, so he asked me to roast it for him.

We did it together and he had it throughout the night. We had a very nice laugh. The week after that he passed away.

It means a lot being there for people at Christmas, especially if people have been struggling. When you’re there it's a relief for them. I don’t see it as a sacrifice though. Caring doesn’t stop just because it’s the holidays. Often this is the time of year when families need us most. If giving up a few hours of my Christmas means that somebody else can spend theirs in the own home, in a familiar setting surrounded by the people who love them, then I’m happy to do that.’

eventName: Carol Concert & Walk in the Sea
story:
Every Christmas the RNLI in Teignmouth hold two events to raise money to support the lifesaving work of their lifeboat and its volunteer crew.

Unfortunately, due to the Covid-19 pandemic both the annual Carol Service and the Boxing Day Walk in the Sea are able to take place in their normal manner.

The Carol Service normally attracts a congregation of over 400 people and raises in excess of £800, but it is also a social occasion when the people of Teignmouth have an opportunity to show their appreciation what the volunteer crew do for our community and for those that visit the town each year. This year the service will be going on-line to allow our community to still take part and to celebrate the work of their local lifeboat and its crew.

The Walk in the Sea has been a very popular and well-supported Boxing Day event for 18 years, when 400 or more brave souls rush into the sea at 11am, clad in a wide variety of costumes, most of them rushing out again even faster a minute or two later . The event enjoys very wide publicity, with over 2,000 spectators gathering on the promenade. Bucket collections and registration donations raise in excess of £8,000 each year but sadly the event has had to be cancelled.

The Teignmouth Lifeboat stations income, already severely depleted, will lose two of its biggest sources of income, but we hope that those of you that would normally take part in these events or support them will consider making a donation to support the lifesaving work of the Teignmouth Lifeboat and its volunteer crew by donating via this Just Giving Page.

Thank you for your support and Happy Christmas from all of us at Teignmouth RNLI.
